user_request: A poem about friendship being a gift that lasts a lifetime.

revision_history.draft:
**The Gift**

You knew the left shoe had no tongue years ago,
still laced it up every morning anyway.
I watched you. Not because I needed watching
but because you were patient in a way
that looks suspiciously like practice—
the kind of habit no one calls a virtue.

We didn't say friendship wouldn't last.
We said nothing. We wore out the heel
of several conversations, turned them over,
bit by bit the rubber came away from the canvas sole,
and we carried on with just the stitched-on shape
of what it was supposed to be.

You inherited my shoes. Not literally—
I'd have sent them back if you'd asked—but
the ones I wore past the point where leather cracks
along the seam and won't heal.
The kind of damage that requires tacks,
that gets bashed inside a door frame every now and then
and holds together anyway.

You wore them to a funeral. That's not why I mention it.
It's because you sat on my couch afterward,
untied them, ran your thumb across the stitched tongue,
the worn seam that kept coming back no matter how many times
we said *enough, throw them out*—and then didn't.

We have those same tacks in every shelf unit we build together.
Not nailed down. Handed loosed to whoever stumbles over them,
because nobody's finished being clumsy by thirty-five.

You'll notice the shoe has no tongue.
You'll step on it occasionally. We both will.
And that's how it is with most things
we keep after they stop being new—
not because we value the object, exactly,
but because we've worn our gratitude into the leather
and can't imagine discarding what holds the shape
of every hallway we've walked through silence.

There's a crack along the side now, near the heel.
You'll feel it before you see it. That's how this works—
the body ahead of the eye,
remembering damage before memory does.
We won't fix it. We'll keep putting our weight on it
and it will keep holding us, itsastretcher,
its worn circumference, still doing exactly what a shoe was made to do:

keep you from falling down again and again.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The central conceit — friendship as a shoe worn to the point of uselessness, kept not for warmth but for the habit of carrying weight — is genuinely strong and earns its space. The crack near the heel (line 29) is the poem's single most alive image: it does real sensory work before the reader has been told what to feel about it. That instinct should govern more of the piece.

The line "We both will" — where "we" splits between speaker and addressee mid-phrase — is a sharp structural move that avoids direct address cliché while enacting the shared experience the poem describes. It's doing something interesting with syntax before it knows it.

The tacks in shelf units (lines 34–36) are concrete, quiet, and well-placed as an image of unfinished repair. That detail belongs to this poem and no other.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Abstraction bloat — lines 5–10 especially.** "Not because I needed watching / but because you were patient in a way — / the kind of habit no one calls a virtue." This is the poem explaining its own metaphor to itself. The ellipsis and dash already signal vagueness; then it says *more* about what patience looks like that dilutes the shoe image. **Direction:** Cut or compress this passage entirely. Let the left shoe without a tongue do the work of establishing observation. Trust the object.

**Cliché proximity — lines 13–16.** "Turned them over, / bit by bit the rubber came away from the canvas sole, / and we carried on with just the stitched-on shape" reads like a catalog of worn-out things that could apply to anything. The stitching-on-shape line is almost decorative. **Direction:** Anchor this passage in one specific detail — what does the speaker actually see? A pebble caught in thread? A particular kind of wear that *only* shoes get?

**Sentimentality / editorializing — lines 17–20.** "You inherited my shoes" and the explanation that follow ("Not literally — / I'd have sent them back if you'd asked") are the poem telling us what to think about gratitude rather than letting the objects carry that weight. The shoe is already doing this; the prose around it explains it away. **Direction:** Remove or radically compress these lines. Let the inheritance be implicit in the image of worn-out soles.

**Redundancy — "wear out" / "worn out" (lines 8, 12).** Same phrase in adjacent lines. The poem is more efficient elsewhere; here it's repeating itself. **Direction:** Choose one and cut the other.

**Weak line break — line 30.** "We both will" breaks on a weak syntactic beat. It reads

revision_history.draft:
You knew the left shoe had no tongue years ago,
still laced it up every morning anyway.
I watched. Not because I needed watching
but because you were patient in a way—
the kind of habit that looks like practice.

The leather cracked along the seam where heel meets arch.
Not evenly. One side pulled tight, the other
worn thin enough to see through. You kept wearing them.

We have those same tacks in every shelf unit we build together:
not nailed down but handed loose to whoever stumbles,
because nobody's finished being clumsy by thirty-five.

You wore the shoes to a funeral.
Said nothing on the drive home except where you parked
and I walked behind your car carrying a bag of bread.
We didn't say friendship wouldn't last. We didn't say anything—
the way a shoe holds shape after the sole separates from its body,

step by step, heel down, weight shifted,
each landing smaller than the one before it.

There's a crack now along the side near where your foot goes in.
You'll feel it before you see it—the body ahead of the eye,
remembering damage the memory hasn't caught up with yet.
We won't fix it. We keep putting our weight on it
and it keeps holding us, itsastretcher,
its worn circumference, still doing exactly what a shoe was made to do:

keep you from falling down again and again.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The crack along the side near the heel (line 29) — "You'll feel it before you see it" — is the poem's single most alive moment. It does real sensory and emotional work simultaneously: a body of knowledge preceding vision, a premonition of failure registered in touch first. That image earns everything around it.

The line "We both will" where "we" splits between speaker and addressee mid-phrase is sharp and enacts the shared experience the poem describes rather than explaining it. The syntax does something interesting before it knows it.

The tacks in shelf units (lines 34–36) are quiet, specific, and well-placed as an image of unfinished repair. That detail belongs to this poem and no other.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Redundancy — "wear out" / "worn out" (lines 8, 12).** Same phrase in adjacent lines. The poem is more efficient elsewhere; here it's repeating itself. **Direction:** Choose one and cut the other. Line 12 already has "worn," line 8 can sharpen to something more precise.

**Abstraction bloat — lines 5–10 especially.** "Not because I needed watching / but because you were patient in a way — / the kind of habit no one calls a virtue" is the poem explaining its own metaphor to itself. The ellipsis and dash already signal vagueness; then it says *more* about what patience looks like that dilutes the shoe image. **Direction:** Cut or compress this passage entirely. Let the left shoe without a tongue do the work of establishing observation. Trust the object.

**Cliché proximity — lines 13–16.** "Turned them over, / bit by bit the rubber came away from the canvas sole, / and we carried on with just the stitched-on shape" reads like a catalog of worn-out things that could apply to anything. The stitching-on-shape line is almost decorative. **Direction:** Anchor this passage in one specific detail — what does the speaker actually see? A pebble caught in thread? A particular kind of wear that *only* shoes get?

**Sentimentality / editorializing — lines 17–20.** "You inherited my shoes" and the explanation that follow ("Not literally — / I'd have sent them back if you'd asked") are the poem telling us what to think about gratitude rather than letting the objects carry that weight. The shoe is already doing this; the prose around it explains it away. **Direction:** Remove or radically compress these lines. Let the inheritance be implicit in the image of worn-out soles.

revision_history.draft:
You knew the left shoe had no tongue years ago,
still laced it up every morning anyway.
I watched—not because I needed watching
but because you were patient in a way
the kind of habit that looks like practice.

The leather cracked along the seam where heel meets arch,
one side pulled tight, one worn thin enough to read through.
You kept wearing them. We have those same tacks
in every shelf unit we build together:
not nailed down but handed loose to whoever stumbles—
because nobody's finished being clumsy by thirty-five.

You wore the shoes to a funeral. On the drive home,
Said where you parked and I walked behind your car
carrying bread. The rust stripe on I-4,
the same hum of interstate traffic, our two quiet voices
falling somewhere between argument and nothing at all—
that's how it worked.

Now there's a dent along the side near where your foot goes in.
You'll feel it before you see it—the body ahead of the eye,
remembering damage the memory hasn't caught up with yet.
We won't fix it. We keep putting our weight on it
and it keeps holding us, its worn circumference,
still doing exactly what a shoe was made to do:

keep you from falling down again and again.

The lace frays where you tie it. I'll add the second knot,
watching how tight you pull before letting go—
that hesitation, almost like believing
the thread might hold on its own.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The dent along the side near where the foot goes in (line 29) — "You'll feel it before you see it" — is the poem's single most alive moment. That image earns everything around it: sensory, emotional, and structurally precise.

The line "We keep putting our weight on it / and it keeps holding us" has genuine force as a refrain. It shifts slightly between stanzas without losing its object: the shoe remains a shoe, but the relationship's weight deepens. The second knot (line 39–40) is also sharp — watching someone tie a lace before letting go, that hesitation *almost* believing the thread might hold on its own.

The cracked leather seam (lines 8–12) has texture and specificity: "one side pulled tight, one worn thin enough to read through." That "read through" is good — it lets the object speak without commentary.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Redundancy — "keep you from falling down again and again."** The refrain says this twice (lines 41–43), and both instances are nearly identical. Direction: Make the second instance different — change what's being repeated, or cut one entirely.

**Line 25 — "itsastretcher"** is a typo that reads as intentional fragmentation but doesn't land because it's uncontrolled. Fix it. If this was deliberate compression of "stretcher," do something more legible first and let the line break create the compression.

**Lines 17–20 (the inherited/shoes explanation).** The prose passage explains what the objects already dramatize. "Not literally" is the poem telling us not to be too literal, which is redundant with the image. Direction: Cut entirely or replace with one concrete detail — who touched this shoe last before you got it? What did that hand do?

**Line 37 — "its worn circumference."** The adjective "worn" appears twice in three lines (lines 36–38). Direction: Choose one.

**Line 24 — "rust stripe on I-4."** This is a scene detail, but it's generic highway language. If this matters, make it specific: what kind of rust? What does the speaker actually see from inside the car?

### Revision Guidance

The poem has found its shape in lines 1–32. Cut the final six lines entirely — "itsastretcher" typo aside, the repetition flattens the ending and the closing simile ("keep you from falling down") moves away from the object toward sentiment.

Rebuild the ending with something closer to the dent image: what does the shoe do at its breaking point? That's where the poem lives. The refrain can stay but needs sharpening — make each instance slightly different in context so tension

revision_history.draft:
You knew the left shoe had no tongue years ago,
still laced it up every morning anyway.
I watched—not because I needed watching
but because you were patient in a way
the kind of habit that looks like practice.

The leather cracked along the seam where heel meets arch,
one side pulled tight, one worn thin enough to read through.
You kept wearing them. We have those same tacks
in every shelf unit we build together:
not nailed down but handed loose to whoever stumbles—
because nobody's finished being clumsy by thirty-five.

You wore the shoes to a funeral. On the drive home,
said where you parked and I walked behind your car
carrying bread. The rust stripe on I-4,
the same hum of interstate traffic, our two quiet voices
falling somewhere between argument and nothing at all—
that's how it worked.

Now there's a dent along where your foot goes in.
You'll feel it before you see it—the body ahead of the eye,
remembering damage the memory hasn't caught up with yet.
We won't fix it. We keep putting our weight on it
and it keeps holding us, its worn circumference,
still doing exactly what a shoe was made to do:

keep you from slipping off.

The lace frays where you tie it. I'll add the second knot—
watching how tight you pull before letting go—
that hesitation, almost like believing
the thread might hold on its own.

You sat on the bed and pressed your heel against it.
It didn't give. It just sat there,
its worn circumference, still doing
exactly what a shoe was made to do:

keep you from falling down again.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The dent along the side near where the foot goes in (line 29) — "You'll feel it before you see it" — is the poem's single most alive moment. That image earns everything around it: sensory, emotional, and structurally precise.

The line "We keep putting our weight on it / and it keeps holding us, its worn circumference," has genuine force as a refrain. It shifts slightly between stanzas without losing its object: the shoe remains a shoe, but the relationship's weight deepens.

The lace fraying where you tie it (line 38–40) is sharp — watching someone tie a lace before letting go, that hesitation *almost* believing the thread might hold on its own. The verb "hesitation" works here because it stays physical; it doesn't reach for feeling.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Redundancy — "keep you from falling down again and again."** The refrain says this twice (lines 41–43), and both instances are nearly identical. Direction: Make the second instance different in meaning or cut one entirely. The first instance at line 38 already does that work more concretely.

**Line 25 — "itsastretcher" typo.** Fix it. If this was intentional compression of "stretcher," do something more legible first, then let the line break create compression.

**Lines 17–20 (the inherited/shoes explanation).** The prose passage explains what the objects already dramatize. Direction: Cut entirely or replace with one concrete detail — who touched this shoe last before you got it? What did that hand do?

**Line 37 — "its worn circumference."** The adjective "worn" appears twice in three lines (lines 36–38). Direction: Choose one.

**Line 24 — "rust stripe on I-4."** This is a scene detail, but it's generic highway language. If this matters, make it specific: what kind of rust? What does the speaker actually see from inside the car?

### Revision Guidance

The dent image (lines 29–31) is the poem's center of gravity — keep that and build outward from there. Cut or radically compress lines 17–20; let the objects do their own work without editorial explanation.

Rebuild the ending with something closer to the dent: what does the shoe do at its breaking point? That's where the poem lives. The refrain can stay but needs sharpening — make each instance slightly different in context so tension builds rather than flattening.

The second knot passage (lines 38–40) is nearly perfect as a gesture. Extend that physical attention into more of the body: hands, feet, weight on pavement. Stay inside the object's logic and

final_poem:
You knew the left shoe had no tongue years ago,
still laced it up every morning anyway.
I watched—not because I needed watching
but because you were patient in a way
the kind of habit that looks like practice.

The leather cracked along the seam where heel meets arch—
one side pulled tight, one worn thin enough to read through.
You kept wearing them. We have those same tacks
in every shelf unit we build together:
not nailed down but handed loose to whoever stumbles—
because nobody's finished being clumsy by thirty-five.

On the drive home from a funeral,
said where you parked and I walked behind your car
carrying bread. The rust stripe on I-4,
the same hum of interstate traffic, our two quiet voices
falling somewhere between argument and nothing at all—
that's how it worked.

There's a dent along where your foot goes in.
You'll feel it before you see it—the body ahead of the eye,
remembering damage the memory hasn't caught up with yet.
We won't fix it. We keep putting our weight on it
and it keeps holding us, its worn circumference,
still doing exactly what a shoe was made to do:

keep you from slipping off.

The lace frays where you tie it. I'll add the second knot—
watching how tight you pull before letting go—
that hesitation, almost like believing
the thread might hold on its own.

You sat on the bed and pressed your heel against it.
It didn't give. It just sat there,
its worn circumference, still doing
exactly what a shoe was made to do:

keep you from falling down again.
